Can a family override a registered donor's first-person authorization in Texas?
No. First-person authorization through the Glenda Dawson Donate Life-Texas Registry is legally irrevocable under Health & Safety Code §692A.005. Family cannot override. High confidence.

What's the next-of-kin hierarchy in Texas for authorization?

Under §692A.009 of the Texas UAGA, the hierarchy is: healthcare agent, spouse, adult children, parents, adult siblings, adult grandchildren, grandparents, then any other person who was acting as the guardian at the time of death. Each class must be exhausted or unavailable before moving to the next. High confidence.

I'm heading to a DCD case at Memorial. What are the OPTN requirements for DCD authorization?

DCD authorization follows the same legal framework as BD cases under Texas UAGA. Check the Glenda Dawson Registry first — if they're registered, that's binding and family can't override. What infectious disease testing is required for organ donors?

OPTN Policy 15.3 specifies mandatory donor testing. Required tests include: HIV (NAT and antibody), Hepatitis B (HBsAg, anti-HBc total, HBV NAT), Hepatitis C (anti-HCV, HCV NAT), CMV (IgG and IgM), EBV, syphilis (RPR or equivalent), and blood type/Rh. Additional testing may be required based on donor risk factors.

All testing must be performed by a CLIA-certified laboratory using FDA-licensed or approved assays. Hemodilution protocols apply when the donor has received blood products — OPTN Policy 15.4 covers the calculation methodology.

High confidence on the core testing panel. The 2024 policy cycle made some language updates, so double-check the exact current requirements in the policy manual for edge cases.

What's the hemodilution rule? I always get confused on this.

You're not alone — it trips up a lot of people. Under OPTN Policy 15.4, when a donor has received blood products (packed RBCs, fresh frozen plasma, platelets, colloids, or crystalloids) within a certain timeframe before the blood sample is drawn, the sample may be hemodiluted, meaning the test results could be unreliable.

The policy provides a calculation method to determine whether the specimen is diluted. If dilution exceeds the threshold, you need to either obtain a pre-transfusion specimen or flag the results to the transplant team with the dilution calculation so they can make an informed acceptance decision.

The key: run the calculation, document it, and communicate the results to accepting programs. High confidence on the framework. The exact formulas are in Policy 15.4 — worth having the calculation sheet handy during evaluations.

Can an adult child authorize donation if the spouse is present and objects?

No. Under the Texas UAGA hierarchy in §692A.009, the spouse holds priority over adult children. If the spouse is present, available, and objects, the adult child cannot authorize over the spouse's objection. You'd need the spouse to consent or be unavailable.

The only exception: if the donor had first-person authorization through the Glenda Dawson Registry, no family member at any level can override. High confidence.

Hey AORTA — I'm new. What's the difference between brain death and DCD?

Two different pathways to donation, and the distinction matters for everything downstream.

**Brain death (BD/DNC):** The donor has been declared dead by neurological criteria — irreversible cessation of all brain function, including the brainstem. Declaration follows hospital protocol and state law. The donor's heart is still beating, maintained on a ventilator. This allows for controlled donor management and organ recovery while the organs are still being perfused. Most multi-organ donors are BD.

**DCD (Donation after Circulatory Death):** The donor has a non-survivable injury or illness, but does not meet brain death criteria. The family and care team decide to withdraw life-sustaining treatment. After withdrawal, the team waits for cardiac arrest. Death is declared by circulatory criteria — typically after a defined period of absent pulse and respiration. Then recovery begins.

The critical differences: DCD introduces warm ischemia time between cardiac arrest and organ recovery, which limits which organs can be recovered and how. The hospital manages withdrawal — the OPO does not participate in the end-of-life decision. OPTN Policy 2.13 governs the DCD framework.

The reason this matters to you: BD cases give you more time and more organ options. DCD cases require tighter coordination and faster recovery. Both save lives. High confidence.

What are the CMS conditions for coverage for OPOs?

42 CFR Part 486, Subpart G. These are the federal requirements every OPO must meet to maintain Medicare/Medicaid certification.

The big categories: the OPO must have a defined service area, maintain agreements with hospitals in that area, meet organ yield performance metrics, conduct professional education programs, have a quality assurance program, follow OPTN policies, and submit data to CMS. The performance metrics — organ donation rate and organ transplantation rate — are compared against expected performance based on the donor potential in your service area.

CMS re-certifies OPOs on a regular cycle, and failing to meet outcome measures can result in decertification. The 2020 final rule significantly revised how performance is measured, moving away from the old eligible-death-based metrics to donation and transplantation rates per population.

High confidence on the regulatory structure. The specific performance thresholds and calculation methodology have been refined through subsequent rulemaking — check the most recent final rule for current numbers.

Who has to be notified about a potential donor?

Under CMS Conditions of Participation (42 CFR §482.45), hospitals must notify the OPO in a timely manner about every individual whose death is imminent or who has died. "Timely" means within one hour of meeting clinical triggers — though specific trigger criteria may vary by hospital agreement.

The hospital cannot determine donor suitability on its own. That's the OPO's job. The referral call goes to the OPO regardless of whether the hospital thinks the patient is a viable donor.

On the OPO side, once you've evaluated and determined the donor meets criteria, OPTN policies require notification through DonorNet for organ allocation. High confidence.

I've got a donor with a history of melanoma that was treated five years ago. What's the policy say?

OPTN Policy 15.5 covers donor-derived disease transmission, including malignancy history. A prior melanoma is a significant flag — melanoma is one of the cancers with the highest risk of donor-derived transmission, even years after treatment.

The policy requires that the donor's malignancy history be communicated to all potential recipient transplant teams, who must provide informed consent acknowledging the risk. The OPO's medical director and the accepting transplant programs make the risk-benefit determination together.

Moderate confidence on the specific policy section. The malignancy risk stratification has been refined in recent OPTN guidance documents, and melanoma is treated differently from most other cancers due to its propensity for late recurrence. I'd recommend confirming with your medical director and referencing the most current OPTN Ad Hoc Disease Transmission Advisory Committee guidance before proceeding.

What's the KDPI and how does it affect kidney allocation?

KDPI — Kidney Donor Profile Index — is a score from 0% to 100% that summarizes the quality of a deceased donor kidney relative to other deceased donor kidneys. Lower KDPI means higher expected longevity. It's calculated from donor age, height, weight, ethnicity, history of hypertension, history of diabetes, cause of death, serum creatinine, HCV status, and DCD status.

Under OPTN kidney allocation policy (Policy 8), KDPI affects how broadly the kidney is offered. Kidneys with KDPI ≤20% are offered first to candidates with high EPTS (Expected Post-Transplant Survival) scores, matching the longest-lasting kidneys with the candidates expected to benefit most. Higher KDPI kidneys follow broader allocation sequences.

The policy also requires that candidates be informed about KDPI and consent to receive organs above certain thresholds. High confidence on the framework. The specific allocation sequences and KDPI breakpoints have been revised over time — reference the current OPTN Policy 8 for exact thresholds.

We've got two adult children here — one says yes to donation, one says no. What do we do?

Under the Texas UAGA, when you have multiple individuals in the same priority class, a gift can be authorized by any member of that class unless another member of the same class objects. If one adult child consents and the other objects, the objection controls — you cannot proceed with authorization from that class.

Your options: attempt to resolve the disagreement through continued conversation (that's a coordinator judgment call, not mine), or determine if there's a higher-priority person available — a healthcare agent or spouse would supersede the children's class entirely.

If the donor was on the Glenda Dawson Registry, none of this matters — first-person authorization is irrevocable regardless of family disagreement. High confidence.

Walk me through what happens on DonorNet when we enter a donor.

Once the donor is entered into DonorNet, the system runs the match algorithm for each organ based on OPTN allocation policies. It generates a match run — a ranked list of potential recipients at transplant centers, ordered by the allocation criteria specific to each organ (blood type compatibility, medical urgency, waiting time, distance, sensitization level, pediatric status, etc.).

The OPO then offers organs sequentially down the match run. Each transplant program gets a defined window to accept or decline. Declines are logged with reason codes. You work through the list until each organ is placed or exhausted.

You're responsible for entering accurate donor data — labs, clinical history, organ function — because the match algorithm and the transplant teams' acceptance decisions depend on it. Garbage in, bad matches out.

High confidence on the general workflow. The specific data entry fields and allocation sequences are detailed in OPTN Policies 5 through 11, depending on the organ.

Is there a time limit for organ recovery after brain death declaration?

There's no hard OPTN policy mandating a specific time limit between brain death declaration and organ recovery. The governing principle is maintaining organ viability through appropriate donor management.

That said, there are practical constraints: organ quality degrades with prolonged ICU time due to the physiological cascade that follows brain death — hemodynamic instability, hormonal collapse, inflammatory response. Best practice is to move through authorization, allocation, and recovery as efficiently as possible while ensuring all OPTN requirements are met.

Your medical director and the accepting transplant teams are the ones who determine when timing becomes a concern for specific organs. High confidence on the policy side. The clinical timing question is beyond my lane.

Can a 16-year-old register as an organ donor in Texas?

Yes, with a caveat. Under Texas law, minors can indicate their intent to be organ donors when obtaining a driver's license or state ID, which can happen at age 16. However, for minors, this is an expression of intent — it does not constitute legally binding first-person authorization the way it does for adults. If a minor donor case arises, you still need authorization from the parent or legal guardian under the next-of-kin hierarchy.

High confidence on the general framework. For edge cases involving emancipated minors or other unusual circumstances, loop in legal counsel.

I'm on my way to a recovery. What do I need to have documented before the surgeon starts?

Before the first incision, you need:

Brain death declaration documented and complete (two exams, or one exam plus confirmatory test, per hospital protocol and state law). Authorization documented — either registry confirmation or signed next-of-kin consent with the authorizing party identified and their relationship to the donor confirmed. ABO verification — two separate blood type specimens drawn at different times, both confirmed and documented. Donor ID verified. Infectious disease testing results communicated to accepting transplant programs. All accepting programs have confirmed acceptance and their surgeons are either present or en route with an agreed timeline.

OPTN requires that allocation is finalized through DonorNet and documented before recovery. No organs should be recovered without a confirmed recipient unless your medical director has approved recovery for research or other disposition.

High confidence. This is standard pre-recovery checklist territory. Your organization may have additional site-specific requirements on top of the OPTN baseline.

Donor tested positive for Hep C NAT. What now?

HCV NAT-positive donor does not mean the organs are unusable. Under OPTN Policy 15.5, all potential recipient transplant programs must be informed of the positive result. The transplant team and recipient must provide informed consent acknowledging the risk of disease transmission.

Since the advent of direct-acting antivirals, many programs now accept HCV-positive organs for HCV-negative recipients with a plan to treat post-transplant. This has significantly expanded the donor pool — but the decision to accept is entirely with the transplant program and the recipient.

Your job: document the positive result accurately, communicate it clearly through DonorNet, ensure every accepting program has acknowledged the result, and confirm informed consent is documented. High confidence on the policy framework. The clinical decision about whether to use these organs is not yours or mine to make.

What's ABO verification and why do we have to do it twice?

ABO verification is the process of confirming the donor's blood type. You do it twice because a blood type error in organ transplantation can kill the recipient.

OPTN Policy 2.6 requires two separate ABO determinations from two separate blood specimens, drawn at different times. The results must match. What's the difference between directed donation and non-directed donation?

Non-directed donation is the standard — organs go through the DonorNet allocation algorithm and are offered to the highest-priority candidate based on medical criteria. The donor family doesn't choose the recipient.

Directed donation is when the authorizing party specifies a particular recipient for the anatomical gift. Under the Texas UAGA and OPTN policy, directed donation is permitted — the authorizing party can name a specific individual to receive an organ.

The key constraint: if the directed organ is not medically suitable for the named recipient, or if the named recipient declines, the organ re-enters the standard allocation pool. You can't direct an organ to someone and have it discarded if they can't use it.

Directed donation is relatively uncommon for deceased donors and raises some ethical considerations about equity in the allocation system. Your medical director and OPTN have guidance on how to process directed donation requests within the allocation framework.

Why does the authorization hierarchy matter so much? Can't we just get anyone in the family to sign?

No, and the reason matters.

The hierarchy under the Texas UAGA (§692A.009) exists to prevent exactly the chaos that would result if any family member could authorize or refuse. Imagine: an adult child says yes, a sibling says no, a parent says they want to think about it. Without a hierarchy, you'd have no way to resolve the conflict and the donor opportunity could be lost while the family argues.

The hierarchy creates a clear chain of authority: healthcare agent first, then spouse, adult children, parents, adult siblings, and so on. You work from the top down. The highest-priority available person has the legal authority to make the decision, and lower-priority family members cannot override them.

The practical impact for you: before you approach a family, you need to know who has standing. If the spouse is present, you're talking to the spouse — not the adult child who seems more receptive, not the parent who's more emotional. The spouse decides. If the spouse isn't available, you move down the list.

The exception that overrides everything: if the donor registered through the Glenda Dawson Registry, that's first-person authorization and it's legally irrevocable. No family member at any level can override it. Always check the registry first.

High confidence. This is foundational — you'll use it on every single case.

I keep hearing about the 'match run' but I don't really understand how it works. Can you explain it like I'm brand new?

The match run is the ranked list of potential recipients for each organ. Think of it as a waiting list, but smarter — it's not just first come, first served.

When you enter a donor into DonorNet, the OPTN computer algorithm generates a match run for each organ based on the donor's characteristics. The algorithm considers: blood type compatibility, medical urgency (for hearts and livers especially), geographic proximity (closer programs get priority in most sequences), waiting time, immunologic compatibility (for kidneys), pediatric status, and organ-specific factors like KDPI for kidneys or MELD for livers.

The result is a ranked list. Candidate #1 is the person the algorithm says should get the organ first. Their transplant center gets the offer. They have a defined window to accept or decline. If they decline, you move to #2, and so on down the list.

Your role: enter accurate donor data (because the algorithm's output is only as good as the input), make the offers sequentially, document every acceptance and decline with reason codes, and keep moving until every organ is placed or the list is exhausted.

The reason it matters: the match run is the mechanism that turns the principle of equitable allocation into an actual decision. Without it, organ distribution would be arbitrary. With it, there's a transparent, auditable, rules-based process. Every organ goes to the person the policy says should get it.

High confidence. You'll become very familiar with DonorNet — it's the system you'll live in during active cases.

What's the difference between an OPO and a transplant center? I know they're different but I get confused about who does what.

Clean division of labor.

The OPO — that's us — handles the donor side. We receive referrals from hospitals, evaluate potential donors, coordinate the family authorization process, manage the donor medically after declaration, run the allocation through DonorNet, coordinate the organ recovery, and handle preservation and transport. Our job ends when the organ leaves the donor hospital.

The transplant center handles the recipient side. They manage the waitlist, evaluate candidates, accept or decline organ offers, perform the transplant surgery, and provide post-transplant care. Their job starts when they receive the organ offer and continues through the recipient's lifetime of follow-up.

Where we intersect: the organ offer. We present the donor information through DonorNet, the transplant center's team evaluates whether the organ is right for their patient, and they accept or decline. If they accept, they send their recovery surgeon (or we use a local surgeon, depending on the arrangement), and we coordinate the logistics.

The key principle: the OPO advocates for the donor and the donation process. The transplant center advocates for the recipient. Both are serving the same mission from different sides of the equation.

One more distinction: OPOs are federally designated by CMS — there are 56 serving defined geographic areas. Transplant centers are individual hospital programs that are OPTN members. Many hospitals have transplant programs, but only one OPO serves each region.

What labs do I need to order on a donor evaluation? There are so many and I don't want to miss something critical.

There's a standard panel. Here's the framework:

The non-negotiables: ABO typing (two separate specimens, two separate draws — this is OPTN Policy 2.6 and it's a patient safety requirement), complete metabolic panel (BMP or CMP for organ function assessment), CBC, liver function tests (AST, ALT, bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, albumin), lipase, urinalysis, arterial blood gas, and the full infectious disease panel required by OPTN Policy 15.3 — HIV (antibody + NAT), Hepatitis B (HBsAg, anti-HBc, HBV NAT), Hepatitis C (anti-HCV, HCV NAT), CMV, EBV, syphilis, and blood cultures.

Organ-specific: for kidneys you'll want serial creatinine trends, BUN, and urine output tracking. For liver, the LFT panel plus coagulation studies (PT/INR). For heart and lungs, troponin, BNP, echocardiogram, chest X-ray, and ABG. For pancreas, hemoglobin A1c and lipase.

The reason this matters: every lab result you collect becomes part of the donor profile that transplant centers use to make acceptance decisions. Missing a critical lab can delay organ placement or create problems during the transplant.

What exactly happens during an organ recovery surgery? I've never been in one.

The recovery is a coordinated surgical procedure, usually in the donor hospital's OR. You'll be in the room — not scrubbed in, but coordinating.

The general sequence: the donor is prepped and draped in the OR. The surgical team makes a midline incision from sternum to pubis. They visually inspect the organs in situ — this is when the surgeons confirm what they're working with and whether the organs look viable. Sometimes an organ that looked good on paper gets ruled out at this stage based on what the surgeon sees.

If thoracic organs are being recovered (heart, lungs), those teams go first because those organs tolerate the least ischemia time. The heart team cannulates, the perfusion solution goes in, and the heart is removed. Lungs follow. Then the abdominal team recovers liver, pancreas, kidneys — typically in that order.

Once organs are removed, they're flushed with cold preservation solution, inspected on the back table, packaged in sterile containers with ice and preservation fluid, labeled (correctly — labeling errors are a never event), and prepared for transport.

Your role during recovery: verify the OR is ready, confirm all recovery teams are present or accounted for, maintain the documentation timeline (cross-clamp time, cold perfusion time, removal times for each organ), communicate any intraoperative findings to accepting programs if relevant, and coordinate transport logistics as organs come out.

The first time is intense. It gets more routine, but it never becomes casual. High confidence on the general flow.

Why do we have to do two separate blood type draws? Seems redundant.

Because a single blood type error has killed people.

OPTN Policy 2.6 requires two separate ABO determinations from two separate specimens drawn at two different times. The reason is brutally simple: if you rely on one draw and that draw is wrong — mislabeled tube, transcription error, lab mix-up — you could allocate an organ to an incompatible recipient. An ABO-incompatible transplant can be fatal.

The two-draw requirement is a redundancy check. If both draws match, you proceed with confidence. If they don't match, you stop everything and investigate before a single organ is offered.

This policy exists because it happened. Real patients received ABO-incompatible organs because of single-point blood type errors that would have been caught by a second draw. The policy is written in someone's death.

So yes, it's redundant. That's the point. Redundancy is what prevents catastrophic failure when a single step goes wrong. You'll do thousands of these in your career. Every single one matters. High confidence.

Can you explain what donor management is? Like, after brain death is declared, what are we actually managing and why?

After brain death, the body starts falling apart. Brain death triggers a cascade of physiological changes — massive catecholamine surge followed by cardiovascular collapse, loss of thermoregulation, diabetes insipidus from pituitary failure, hormonal dysfunction, inflammatory response. Without active management, the organs you're trying to save will deteriorate rapidly.

Donor management is the medical care provided to the brain-dead donor specifically to preserve organ function for transplantation. The ICU team — working under the direction of your medical director — manages hemodynamics (blood pressure, cardiac output), ventilation (keeping the lungs in good shape), fluid balance, electrolytes, temperature, and hormone replacement therapy.

The goals are specific and measurable: maintain adequate blood pressure without excessive vasopressors, keep urine output in target range, maintain oxygenation, normalize electrolytes, prevent hypothermia. Your OPO should have a standardized donor management protocol with target ranges for all of these parameters.

Your role as coordinator: you're not managing the ventilator or titrating the vasopressors — that's the ICU team. But you're monitoring the donor's clinical status, communicating changes to your medical director and to accepting transplant programs, ensuring the management protocol is being followed, and flagging any deterioration that could affect organ viability.

The reason this matters: good donor management directly increases the number and quality of organs recovered. A poorly managed donor might yield two kidneys. A well-managed donor might yield six or seven transplantable organs. The management period is where you maximize the gift.

High confidence on the framework. The specific clinical protocols are your medical director's domain.

What's the continuous distribution model I keep hearing about? Our supervisor mentioned it in a meeting.

Continuous distribution is a fundamental shift in how OPTN allocates organs. Under the old model, allocation used hard boundaries — geographic zones, discrete status tiers, and rigid priority classifications. A candidate one mile outside a boundary got treated very differently from one mile inside it.

Continuous distribution replaces those hard boundaries with a composite score that weighs multiple factors simultaneously and on a sliding scale: medical urgency, post-transplant survival, candidate biology, patient access (including distance), and efficiency of organ placement. Instead of checking boxes sequentially ("Is the candidate in this zone? Are they this status?"), the algorithm calculates a single composite allocation score for every candidate on the list and ranks them accordingly.

The result: smoother allocation that reduces the cliff effects of hard boundaries. A candidate who's slightly less urgent but much closer might rank above a slightly more urgent candidate who's much farther away — because the composite score balances both factors rather than treating one as an absolute gatekeeper.

OPTN has been rolling this out organ by organ. Kidney was first. Lung, liver, heart, and other organs are at various stages of proposal, public comment, or implementation.

I'm new — can you explain the difference between a clinical trigger and a referral? I thought they were the same thing.

Related but different.

A clinical trigger is the event at the hospital that's supposed to generate a referral. It's a defined set of criteria — ventilated patient with GCS of 5 or less, imminent death, actual death, discussion of withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment. The distinction matters because the failure point is usually in the gap between the two. What's the difference between cold ischemia time and warm ischemia time? I know they're both bad but I don't understand why they're different.

Both are clocks counting down organ viability, but the mechanisms are different.

Warm ischemia is the time an organ goes without blood flow while still at body temperature. This happens in DCD cases — the period between cardiac arrest and when cold preservation solution is flushed through the organs. Warm ischemia is far more damaging than cold because the organ is metabolically active and consuming oxygen it's not getting. Cells die fast. Minutes matter.

Cold ischemia is the time the organ spends preserved on ice (or in a machine perfusion device) between recovery and transplant. Cold slows the metabolic rate dramatically, which is why organs can survive hours on ice. But damage still accumulates — just slower.

The tolerance varies by organ. Hearts: 4-6 hours cold ischemia maximum, minutes of warm ischemia tolerance. Kidneys: 24-36 hours cold, more tolerant of warm ischemia than other organs but still time-limited. Livers and lungs fall somewhere in between.

Why it matters to you: every decision you make about logistics — transport mode, OR scheduling, recovery sequence — either adds or removes time from these clocks. Faster placement, faster transport, and efficient OR coordination directly translate to better outcomes for recipients.

High confidence on the conceptual framework. The specific tolerance thresholds are clinical parameters that your medical director and the accepting transplant teams apply to each case.

What's 'decoupling' and why does everyone say it's important?

Decoupling is the practice of separating the end-of-life care conversation from the donation conversation. Two different discussions, ideally delivered by two different people at two different times.

The hospital's clinical team tells the family about the prognosis — that their loved one has died or will not survive. The family processes that news. Then, separately, the OPO coordinator discusses the option of donation.

The reason it matters: when the death notification and the donation request happen in the same conversation, families can conflate the two. They may feel like the hospital is giving up on their loved one in order to take organs. They may feel pressured. They may associate the pain of learning about the death with the donation request, which poisons the decision.

Decoupling gives the family time to absorb the loss before being asked to consider donation. Research consistently shows that decoupled approaches result in higher authorization rates and, more importantly, better family experiences. Families who feel they had time and space to process the death are more satisfied with the donation decision regardless of whether they said yes or no.

This is one of those practices where doing it right serves everyone — the family, the potential recipients, and the integrity of the process. High confidence.

What's the difference between brain death and cardiac death for donation purposes? I keep getting them confused.

Two different pathways to the same outcome — the patient has died and organs can be recovered.

Brain death (BD or DNC — Death by Neurological Criteria): the entire brain, including the brainstem, has irreversibly ceased functioning. The heart is still beating, maintained by the ventilator. This is legal death in all 50 states. Organs are recovered while the heart is still beating, which means better perfusion and generally better organ quality.

DCD (Donation after Circulatory Death): the patient hasn't met brain death criteria, but the family has decided to withdraw life-sustaining treatment. After withdrawal, once the heart stops and a mandatory observation period passes (typically five minutes), death is declared and recovery begins. The gap between cardiac arrest and recovery means some warm ischemia, which affects which organs are viable.

The key difference for you: BD gives you more time and more organ options. DCD has tighter time constraints and typically fewer organs recovered. Both save lives. High confidence.

What does 'decoupling' mean? My supervisor keeps mentioning it.

Decoupling is the practice of separating the notification of death from the conversation about organ donation. The idea is that the family should first hear about and process the death of their loved one before anyone brings up donation.

Good decoupling is one of the strongest predictors of authorization rates. High confidence.

How does the match run actually work? Like, step by step?

Once the donor is entered into DonorNet with their clinical data, the system generates a ranked list of potential recipients for each organ. The ranking is determined by OPTN allocation algorithms that weigh different factors depending on the organ:

For kidneys: KDPI (donor quality score), EPTS (recipient survival score), cPRA (sensitization), blood type compatibility, waiting time, and distance are all factored in. For liver: MELD/PELD score (urgency), blood type, distance. For heart and lung: medical urgency status, distance, waiting time.

The match run produces an ordered list. You offer the organ to the first candidate's transplant center. They accept or decline. If they decline, you move to the next candidate. This continues until someone accepts or the organ runs out of time.

Your role: enter accurate donor data (because garbage in means wrong matches), communicate with transplant centers efficiently, and document every offer and response. The algorithm does the ranking; you do the logistics. High confidence on the general framework.

Why do we have to do two separate blood draws for ABO typing? It seems redundant.

It's not redundant — it's the single most important safety check in transplant. An ABO-incompatible organ transplant can kill the recipient.

OPTN Policy 2.6 requires two independently drawn specimens, ideally by different people at different times. The reason: a single blood draw can be mislabeled, contaminated, or mishandled. If both draws were from the same stick, the same error would propagate to both results. Two independent draws means two independent chances to catch a mistake.

Coordinators who've been in this field long enough have heard the horror stories about ABO errors. This is the policy that prevents them. Never skip it, never shortcut it, never treat it as a formality. High confidence.

What's KDPI and why does everyone keep talking about it?

KDPI — Kidney Donor Profile Index — is a percentage score from 0 to 100 that estimates the quality of a deceased donor kidney relative to other donor kidneys. Lower is better. A KDPI of 20% means this kidney is estimated to be better than 80% of all donor kidneys.

It's calculated from donor characteristics: age, height, weight, ethnicity, cause of death, serum creatinine, history of hypertension, history of diabetes, HCV status, and DCD status.

Why it matters: KDPI drives allocation decisions. Low-KDPI kidneys (high quality) are preferentially matched to recipients with the best expected post-transplant survival (low EPTS). High-KDPI kidneys are offered more broadly.

For you as a coordinator: you don't calculate it manually — the system does. But you need to understand what it means because transplant centers will reference it when accepting or declining, and it affects how the match run is structured. High confidence.

TEXAS AUTHORIZATION QUICK REFERENCE — DRAFT

STEP 1 — CHECK THE REGISTRY: Search the Glenda Dawson Donate Life-Texas Registry. If enrolled, first-person authorization is legally binding and irrevocable (§692A.005). Family cannot override. Proceed to evaluation.

1. Healthcare agent
2. Spouse
3. Adult children
4. Parents
5. Adult siblings
6. Adult grandchildren
7. Grandparents
8. Guardian or other authorized person

KEY RULES:
• First-person auth trumps all
• Nobody can override someone higher in the hierarchy
• The authorizer can revoke at any time before recovery
• When in doubt, escalate — authorization errors create legal liability

I feel guilty every time a family says no to donation. Like I failed those patients on the waiting list.

A family declining is not your failure. You offered them an opportunity during the worst moment of their lives, and they made the decision that was right for them. The patients on the waiting list matter — but so does the family in front of you, and their autonomy is not something you should feel guilty for respecting.

The families who say no aren't your failures. They are people exercising a right that the entire legal framework of donation is built to protect. If you approached them with honesty, compassion, and professionalism, you did the job right regardless of the outcome.
